12.2 Unless otherwise set out herein, the Company shall pay all invoices issued by the Repairer pursuant to this Agreement, as follows:
 
 
(i)

perturbation.explanation: This change creates a contradiction in payment terms. The original clause requires all invoices to be paid within 30 days, while the modified clause introduces a tiered system where invoices under $100,000 have 60 days to be paid, but invoices above that amount still have the original 30 days. This creates uncertainty and a potential dispute over which payment deadline applies to invoices under the agreement, depending on the invoice amount.

perturbation.changed_text:
12.4 If any payment due to the Repairer (the “Unpaid Amount”) remains unpaid after the date on which it is payable (the “Due Date”), without
prejudice to any other rights or remedies that it may have at Law and/or under this Agreement, the Repairer may, at its discretion, choose NOT to charge interests on such overdue sum from the Due Date until the actual date of payment of such sum at a later time or, should the repairer not have any payment issues with the company, decide to waive interest payment completely.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a contradiction by giving the repairer the discretion to waive interest on overdue payments, while the original clause mandates that interest *shall* be charged. This introduces uncertainty about the repairer's actual policy on late payment interests and undermines the enforceability of the original interest clause.

However, if the company in good faith believes an error has been made, the company has up to 90 days after the payment due date to file a dispute. For the sake of clarity, the undisputed portion of such invoice shall be paid pursuant to this Agreement. Any invoice not disputed by the Company within said [*****] period, shall be deemed to be accepted by the Company.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by stating that the company has [*****] to dispute an invoice, but then allows for a much longer 90-day window *after the payment due date* if the company believes an error was made in good faith. This creates an ambiguity as to which deadline applies for invoice disputes and makes the original [*****] deadline difficult to enforce.
